Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Particle-Resolved Models for Aerosol-Cloud Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Whether aerosols are internally (multicomponent) or externally (one component) mixed impacts aerosol-cloud interactions. The approach of this CAREER project centers on developing innovative modeling tools for quantifying the impact of per-particle (single) aerosol microphysical and chemical properties on aerosol-cloud interactions, on the micro to global scale. The work is motivated by growing observational evidence that shows tremendous variations in the chemistry and dynamics at a single-particle level. At present, however, the impacts of these variations are largely unquantified since in current regional or global models this complexity is not well-represented. This contributes to the large uncertainties in assessing the impact of aerosols on climate, limiting us from predicting the future impacts of air pollution on climate change.

A comprehensive education and outreach plan that focuses on enhancing "climate literacy" along with the the recruitment of students into the STEM fields is integrated with this research. The educational program targets students and teachers at the middle-school level, students at the undergraduate and graduate levels, and the wider community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary

This project developed and applied innovative modeling tools for quantifying the impact of per-particle aerosol microphysical and chemical properties on aerosol-cloud interactions. The project was motivated by growing observational evidence that shows tremendous diversity in the chemistry and dynamics at a single-particle level. Yet, we were lacking the tools to quantify the impacts of these diversities, which introduces "unknown unknowns", i.e., structural uncertainty in these models, and limits us from predicting the future impacts of air pollution on climate change. Closely coupled to this research effort was a comprehensive education and outreach plan that focused on enhancing climate literacy and the recruitment of students into the STEM fields, targeting students and teachers at the middle-school level, students at the undergraduate and graduate levels, and the wider community. 

Intellectual Merit

The outcomes of the project consist of (1) theoretical developments of metrics for the diversity of aerosol particles and their applications to observations. We showed that the diversity metrics can be used as a predictor for the error in climate-relevant aerosol properties due to simplifying assumptions about mixing state.  (2) Method development for multi-scale aerosol simulations including error quantification and coarse-graining. The project led to the first application of machine learning techniques to bridge the gap between detailed process modeling and a large-scale climate model. (3) High-performance simulations of atmospheric aerosol processes and climate impacts using the Blue Waters supercomputer. This revealed the extent to which the chemical composition of particles must be resolved to accurately represent aerosol radiative effects and cloud interactions, something that previously was not possible.

Broader impacts

The immediate benefit of this work is the development of a new, innovative method for representing aerosol-cloud interactions in current micro-, regional- and global-scale models. The improved understanding of aerosol and cloud modeling processes generated by this research is an important contribution to reducing the uncertainty in the predictions of future climate change. This is a subject of clear and present significance to a broad scientific community, and to governmental policy at national and international levels. Our codes are freely available as open source code. We added extensive online documentation for all PartMC subroutines and on the format of input and output files and published journal articles describing our work.

The outcomes of the educational and outreach activities include: (1) Training and professional development for several graduate students (M.S. and Ph.D.), undergraduate students, as well as several middle school teachers. (2) Involvement of our undergraduate student chapter of the American Meteorological Society with organizing an outreach event at the UIUC Engineering Open House. This has become one of their big events of the school year and is one of our prime opportunities to connect with the broader community. The undergraduate students learn how to organize such an event and how to communicate effectively with the public. (3) an Atmospheric Sciences middle school curriculum that implements a flipped-classroom model and is cross-referenced with Common Core and Next Generation Science Standards. The material introduces students to topics such as temperature, pressure, and water in the atmosphere, climate and air pollution, as well as severe weather and safety through short instructional videos and critical thinking activities. It is available to download under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License.
